This can benefit them in future when they intend to open up their own companies or hospitals.Looking from another perspective, there are also a significant number of people who are very successful in their fields without going to university. Take for instance those who start their own business. These people depend solely on hard work and luck. Interestingly, for some of them it proved to be a profitable job. To cite an example, Michael Dell who is the founder and the CEO of Dell left college at 19. Initially, he started his computer company in his college dorm room. Eventually, he used his earnings as well as his family's loan in order to progress to be who he is now.In addition, people with natural talents are also most likely to excel in their life. This is especially true in sectors like entertainment and sports. The introduction of increasing number of reality shows have made it possible for all those lucky ones to triumph. To illustrate this further, David Archuleta who was once a nobody has now taken up a large space in hearts of many. Hence, it is evident that individuals born with talents have also a high chance to be successful.To wrap it all up, it is indeed true that university education is pivotal in a person's life in order for one to prosper. However, it would be wrong to say that one's success completely depends on the education he or she receives at the institutions. Natural talent and hard work also contribute to their progress.
llm: The idea that the qualities a person needs to become successful in today's world cannot be learned at a university or similar academic institution is a topic of ongoing debate. While I acknowledge that academic institutions provide a solid foundation for knowledge and skills, I partially agree that success requires qualities that go beyond the realm of academia.Universities and colleges equip students with theoretical knowledge, a strong work ethic, and critical thinking skills, all of which are essential for success. However, qualities like adaptability, resilience, creativity, and effective communication are equally crucial in today's fast-paced and ever-changing world. These soft skills, which are often gained through real-world experiences, internships, and personal interactions, cannot be fully replicated within the confines of a classroom.Moreover, entrepreneurial spirit, emotional intelligence, and the ability to navigate uncertainty are essential qualities for achieving success, particularly in the context of innovation and leadership. These traits are often developed through hands-on experiences, networking, and learning from failures, which may not be adequately addressed in traditional academic settings. Nonetheless, it is also important to recognize that academic institutions can provide a platform for students to develop some of these qualities, such as through project-based learning, group assignments, and extracurricular activities. Therefore, while universities can lay the groundwork, it is the combination of academic learning with practical, real-world experiences that truly fosters the wide range of qualities needed for success in today's world. In conclusion, I believe that while academic institutions play a vital role, they are only one part of the equation for achieving success, and real-world experiences are equally, if not more, important.

question: People should be allowed to continue to work for as long as they want to, and not forced to retire at a particular age such as 60 or 65. Do you agree or disagree?Ê
human: The appropriate age at which a person should stop working is now a much debated issue in the society. Some opine that people should be given the option to choose when they want to call it a day while others oppose this notion. In my personal point of view, the right age for a person to retire should be around 60 years old. I, for one, strongly agree that age should be set as a criterion for people to retire at the aforementioned age due to several reasons that I shall discuss below.First and foremost, if senior workers dominate the working sector, there will be lesser job opportunities for the fresh graduates. As a result, most of them will be forced to take up careers which are poles apart from what they had studied for. To illustrate this further, a medical graduate might find it very disheartened when he had to spend around five precious years studying medicine and at the end of the day, he will have to take up another profession rather than doctor due to the insufficient job opportunities available. On top of that, due to the lack of genuine passion on the work which was not of their option, there is a greater possibility for their performance standard to dwindle at their workplace.Apart from that, not all elderly workers are physically well. Beyond that age, a large proportion of them have an elevated chance of contracting a multitude of health problems such as stress related diseases and cardiovascular illnesses. To cite an example, the stressful life that an aged teacher goes through will definitely take a toll on him. Consequently, they will not be able to give their best in whatever they are doing. Besides, the academic institution will have to pay for his medical bills, resulting in more loss for the institution. Thus, it would indeed be better if at an older age, opportunities are given to the younger ones.Admittedly, the expertise of the senior workers who had retired should never be underestimated. Their invaluable experiences and knowledge in their respective fields such as engineering, medicine, and law can certainly be beneficial to the younger generation. Hence, it is highly recommended that the retiree come over to the companies or hospitals to have regular sessions with the present staffs to bridge the gap between them and to pass on their knowledge.In conclusion, it is indeed evident that age limit should be set for retirement. There will come a certain time when the older generation should hand over the responsibility to the fresh comers who are certainly waiting to be given a choice to prove themselves. After all, retirement not only marks the end of an individual, but also gives him a chance to make up for what he has lost throughout his working life.
llm: The notion of forced retirement at a specific age has been a long-standing debate. While some argue that it is necessary to create job opportunities for younger generations, I firmly believe that people should be allowed to continue working for as long as they want to. Mandatory retirement ages, such as 60 or 65, can be detrimental to individuals who are still capable and willing to contribute to the workforce.Forcing people to retire can lead to a loss of skilled and experienced workers, which can be particularly detrimental to industries that require specialized knowledge and expertise. Furthermore, many people rely on their employment not only for financial stability but also for social interaction and a sense of purpose. Retiring earlier than desired can lead to feelings of isolation and boredom, ultimately affecting their mental and physical health.On the other hand, allowing people to work for as long as they want to can have numerous benefits. It can lead to a more experienced and skilled workforce, as well as increased economic activity. Many older workers are also willing to mentor and train younger employees, which can help to transfer knowledge and skills to the next generation. Additionally, with the rising cost of living and increasing life expectancy, many people may not have enough savings to support themselves in retirement, and continuing to work can provide them with a much-needed income.In conclusion, I strongly agree that people should be allowed to continue working for as long as they want to. It is essential to recognize the value and contributions that older workers can bring to the workforce and to provide them with the opportunity to continue working if they so desire. By doing so, we can create a more diverse, experienced, and skilled workforce that benefits both individuals and society as a whole.

question: Some people claim that public museums and art galleries will not be needed because people can see historical objects and works by using computer. To what extent do you agree or disagree?
human: I believe public museums and art galleries will still be necessary, even though we can see the art works and historical objects online.Most people nowadays prefer to use the Internet to search for art work because the Internet really brings them convenience. We can browse the art work from all over the world at home. However, people may not get a spiritual experience since pictures online are only limited to a screen size. By contrast, the exhibits in museums or galleries are all life size and visitors can get a more direct felling. For example, only when we see the real mummy, can we experience mystique.In order to help visitors to learn more about the exhibits, museums hold various activities which make visitors be part of what they are seeing. For example, at American Museum of Natural History, you can make a bone-by-bone reproduction of the museum's stegosaurus; at Museum of Art in New York, you can look at 17th century instruments while listening to their music. While if you "visit" the museum online, you may not able to get this kind of experience.Seeing an art work on computer screen is not the same as you watch it by your own eyes. For instance, you can't see the texture of the artwork which is very important to study the skills used by the artist. What's more, not all the details of the artwork can be shown on the computer screen. Some details might be dim since the resolution ratio of the screen is not high enough. These may influence the comprehension of the art work or historical objects.In conclusion, I believe we still need museums and art galleries but computers can be introduced to museums and galleries in order to help visitors to know more about the art works or historical objects.
llm: The notion that public museums and art galleries will become obsolete due to the rise of digital technology has sparked a heated debate. While it is true that computers and the internet have made it possible for people to access and view historical objects and artworks from the comfort of their own homes, I strongly disagree that this will render physical museums and galleries unnecessary.On the one hand, digital technology has undoubtedly increased accessibility to cultural and historical content. With just a few clicks, people can now explore exhibitions and view artworks from around the world. This has been particularly beneficial for those with mobility issues or living in remote areas. However, the experience of viewing a digital representation of an artwork or historical object is fundamentally different from seeing it in person.On the other hand, physical museums and galleries offer a unique and immersive experience that cannot be replicated by digital technology. The texture, scale, and context of an artwork or historical object are essential to understanding its significance and impact. Moreover, museums and galleries provide a social and communal space where people can engage with others, share experiences, and participate in guided tours and workshops. The sensory and emotional connections that people make with physical objects and artworks are essential to fostering a deeper understanding and appreciation of culture and history.In conclusion, while digital technology has expanded access to cultural and historical content, it is unlikely to replace the need for physical museums and art galleries. The unique experience and benefits offered by these institutions ensure that they will continue to be relevant and necessary, providing a space for people to engage with and appreciate the richness and diversity of human culture and history.

question: Under British and Australian laws a jury in a criminal case has no access to information about the defendant's past criminal record. This protects the person who is being accused of the crime. Some lawyers have suggested that this practice should be changed and that a jury should be given all the past facts before they reach their decision about the case. Do you agree or disagree?
human: Courts of many countries provide a jury with the history of a defendant, except those of the UK and Australia. Common belief that a jury should obtain all information regarding a suspect has fostered some lawyers to protest against the current rules in those two countries.Many people hold the opinion that past behaviour determines the future actions, which could be the main reason to support the idea of revealing the record to the jury. We must acknowledge that complete data concerning the history of a sued person creates more opportunity for jury members to build an overall picture of defendant's personality. Furthermore, past record might be useful to decide whether a person was able to perform a certain type of crime when it concerns serious crimes, such as kidnapping or a murder.Nevertheless, in order for the jury to come up with an objective decision not depending on the past experience, the court should provide with details relevant to a particular case only. For instance, a defendant with number of past crimes has more chance to be found guilty compared to a person with no or lighter criminal record. Innocent suspects, eventually, can face unfair juridical decision and pay twice for their previous inadequate actions.In conclusion, I am skeptical about disclosing the defendant's history to the jury, with intention to avoid subjective and probable inaccurate verdict. Thus, I strongly support the current laws of Great Britain and Australia, and would not change the regulations on keeping the jury unaware of past actions.
llm: The practice of withholding a defendant's past criminal record from a jury in a criminal case is a long-standing principle in British and Australian laws. The primary purpose of this practice is to ensure that the defendant receives a fair trial, untainted by prejudicial information. I strongly disagree with the suggestion that this practice should be changed and that a jury should be given all the past facts before they reach their decision about the case.If a jury is aware of a defendant's past criminal record, it is likely to influence their decision, potentially leading to an unfair outcome. The jury's role is to determine whether the defendant is guilty of the specific crime they are being tried for, not to punish them for past transgressions. By keeping the defendant's past record hidden, the jury can focus on the evidence presented in the current case, rather than being swayed by irrelevant information.Furthermore, introducing a defendant's past record into the trial could lead to a "guilty by association" mentality, where the jury assumes the defendant is guilty based on their past behavior, rather than the evidence presented. This would undermine the fundamental principle of "innocent until proven guilty" and could result in wrongful convictions.In conclusion, the current practice of withholding a defendant's past criminal record from a jury is essential to ensuring a fair trial. It allows the jury to focus on the evidence presented in the case, rather than being influenced by irrelevant and potentially prejudicial information. Changing this practice could lead to unfair outcomes and undermine the integrity of the justice system. Therefore, I strongly disagree with the suggestion that a jury should be given all the past facts before they reach their decision about the case.

question: University lecturers are now able to put their lectures on the internet for students to read and so the importance of attending face to face lectures has been reduced. Do you believe the use of Internet in formal education is a good idea and what are the effects that the internet has on future academic study?Ê
human: Over the past few decades, the world has witnessed a long stride in technological modernization, especially in field of education. This has enabled university lecturers to post their lessons on the web for the sake of students. Consequently, direct interactions between teachers and learners have been deemphasized. However, the impact of the Internet on schooling is still an intriguing issue which has sparked a heated debate among educationists. Personally, I believe that the Internet will pave way for a more accessible and convenient learning.First and foremost, the Internet is an adequate source of academic information, which will potentially fulfill the needs of university pupils. Nowadays, not only are lectures available online, it is also applicable to find reference e-books as well as multi-aspect documents on the cyberspace. As such, the Internet has grown to become the largest virtual library ever. Moreover, with the use of the Internet, distance and time seem to be no more a hindrance. College students can save their time browsing for necessary information through the web instead of spending hours wandering in bookstores or libraries. Last but not least, the Internet offers a more effective and practical method of studying. While virtual flowcharts and animations may simplify complicated scientific processes, Google and Wikipedia are always accessible for detailed responses to every query.In the near future, the Internet will become an indispensable part in academic training, for the enormous benefits that it brings about. Have you ever imagined what it would be like to stay at home and attend a lecture by a famous speaker in Finland simultaneously? This fairy tale turns out to be true thanks to technical and internet advances.Critics may argue that the Internet have several drawbacks which can affect the education system negatively, for instance internet abuse and black webs. However, we should bear in mind that these problems are mainly triggered by students' wrong approach towards the Internet not the Internet itself. Thus, what we are to do is a change in learners' attitude not an elimination of the Internet from academic study.After analyzing both points of view, I would like to reiterate the necessity of the Internet in learning process. It is obvious that the benefits of the Internet undoubtedly outweigh its disadvantages. However, it is not just the matter of help or hindrance, it is the way you use the cyberspace. Be wise and conscious.
llm: The advent of the internet has revolutionized the way education is delivered, and university lecturers are now able to post their lectures online for students to access. This has led to a reduction in the importance of attending face-to-face lectures, and has sparked debate about the role of the internet in formal education. In my opinion, the use of the internet in formal education is a good idea, and it has both positive and negative effects on future academic study.On the one hand, the internet provides students with unparalleled access to educational resources, allowing them to learn at their own pace and review material as many times as they need. This is particularly beneficial for students who may have missed a lecture or need to reinforce their understanding of complex concepts. Additionally, online lectures can reach a wider audience, increasing accessibility and equality in education.On the other hand, over-reliance on online lectures can lead to a lack of engagement and interaction with instructors and peers, which are essential components of the learning process. Face-to-face lectures provide opportunities for discussion, debate, and clarification, which are difficult to replicate online. Moreover, the absence of non-verbal cues and immediate feedback can hinder the learning experience.In conclusion, while the internet has reduced the importance of attending face-to-face lectures, it is not a replacement for traditional teaching methods. A balanced approach, combining online resources with face-to-face interaction, is likely to yield the best results. As technology continues to evolve, it is crucial to harness its potential to enhance, rather than replace, the academic experience. By doing so, we can ensure that future academic study is enriched, and students are equipped with the skills and knowledge necessary to succeed in an increasingly digital world.

question: Many people in the undeveloped world die from diseases that are curable because they can't afford the medication to treat themselves. Do you believe that drug companies in the developed world should be obliged to make their products available at reduced prices in these undeveloped countries so that people do not die unnecessarily?
human: At present, a large number of patients in poor countries are suffering from deaths caused by lack of medication rather than dangerous diseases. It is suggested that companies in developed countries ought to reduce their price of medicines to avoid such unnecessary deaths.Admittedly, more lives will be saved by the use of effective medicines. The medical industry in developing countries is incapable of producing high-quality drugs. With advanced technology, the developed world has achieved remarkable breakthroughs in making medicines, which can cure a variety of serious illnesses. If people in poorer countries gain access to these drugs, their health situations may be better. The reduction in cost of medicines therefore shows the sign of humanity.However, the current cost of medicines is , in fact, reasonable and based on the medicines' effectiveness. Apparently, the process of researching, testing and producing drugs in masses costs a substantial amount of money. Moreover, these products prove to ensure human health completely. Suppose companies were forced to reduce the cost of drugs, they would make no profit, even running up debt because of production expenditure. Therefore, the measure cannot be adopted, otherwise those companies will go into liquidation. In short, this is not a long-term solution.Fortunately, there are other measures to improve the situation. It is advisable for the government to encourage medical production by supplying land for building factories and reducing part of the taxes. Additionally, charitable organizations can buy medicines from developed countries and distribute to the undeveloped world for free.In conclusion, I disagree with reducing the cost of medicines, which may exacerbate their qualities. Instead, the government and medical foundations should be responsible for the distribution of drugs to the undeveloped world at a more reasonable price.
llm: The disparity in access to medication between developed and undeveloped countries is a pressing global issue. Millions of people in impoverished nations succumb to curable diseases due to the unaffordability of life-saving medications. It is morally imperative to consider the role of drug companies in bridging this healthcare gap. In my opinion, drug companies in the developed world have a social responsibility to make their products available at reduced prices in undeveloped countries.By doing so, these companies can help prevent unnecessary deaths and alleviate the burden of treatable diseases on vulnerable populations. The argument that reducing prices would compromise research and development investments is valid, but it does not justify the loss of human lives. A balanced approach, where companies maintain their profitability while also ensuring accessibility of their medications, can be achieved through tiered pricing models or partnerships with governments and non-profit organizations.Moreover, making medications affordable in undeveloped countries can have long-term benefits for drug companies, including expanding their market reach and fostering goodwill. It is also important to recognize that the current situation is not only a humanitarian crisis but also a significant economic burden, as the loss of productive members of society can hinder a country's development. Therefore, I firmly believe that drug companies should be obliged to make their products available at reduced prices in undeveloped countries, as it is a matter of social justice and a crucial step towards achieving global health equity. By taking this step, we can work towards a future where access to lifesaving medication is a fundamental right, not a privilege reserved for the affluent.

question: Some businesses prohibit smoking in any of their offices. Some governments have banned smoking in all public places. Do you agree or disagree?
human: The awareness on harmful effects from smoking among the general public has put much pressure on the government and private sectors. As a result, some businesses prohibit smoking in their premises and even some governments restrict smoking in public area. It is agreed that the move will do more good by looking at the quality of health and image of a nation in long run.Firstly, it is well known and clinically proven that smoking is extremely hazardous to the smoker and others who have been exposed to the fume over a period of time. Recent death statistic released by the Malaysian Ministry of Health shows that the top killer was lung related diseases caused by smoking. A large proportion of death involved second hand smoker particularly young children and pregnant women who were vulnerable to these lethal diseases. Therefore, the number of fatality can be significantly reduced if a total ban on public smoking is implemented.Secondly, the image of a healthy nation can be promoted when government restricts public smoking by imposing stern penalty to the offender. For instance, the Brunei government had recently enforced a law against smoking in public areas such as cafés, hospital and shopping street. This step has curbed down the numbers of smokers in the country and as a result, Brunei remains a place known for its tranquility and cleanliness. This example shows the benefit of restricting public smoking to a country as a whole.To sum up, the effort to prohibit people from smoking in public area is certainly helping in curtailing the associated health risks and to create a healthy nation. It is hoped that more businesses and governments will follow the same initiatives for the interest of the people and the country.
llm: The issue of smoking in public places and offices has been a topic of debate for many years. While some argue that individuals have the right to smoke wherever they please, I firmly agree that smoking should be prohibited in all public places and offices.First and foremost, smoking poses serious health risks not only to the smoker but also to those around them. Second-hand smoke, also known as passive smoke, has been proven to cause a range of health problems, including lung cancer and heart disease. By banning smoking in public places and offices, governments and businesses can help protect the health of their citizens and employees.Furthermore, smoking can be a significant distraction and disruption in the workplace. The smell of smoke can be unpleasant and irritating to non-smokers, and the frequent breaks that smokers take to smoke can decrease productivity and efficiency. In addition, smoking can also damage property and leave unpleasant odors and stains.Moreover, banning smoking in public places and offices can help to reduce the number of smokers and prevent young people from taking up the habit. If smoking is not allowed in public, it can help to de-normalize the behavior and make it less appealing to others. This can have long-term health benefits for individuals and society as a whole.In conclusion, while some may argue that smoking bans infringe upon individual rights, I firmly believe that the benefits of prohibiting smoking in public places and offices far outweigh any perceived drawbacks. By protecting the health of citizens and employees, and promoting a healthier and more productive environment, governments and businesses can make a positive impact on society. Therefore, I strongly agree that smoking should be banned in all public places and offices.

question: Some people say we humans are harming the Earth through our activities, but other people say we are improving the quality of life on our planet. Which opinion do you agree with ?
human: "Save the planet Earth" is a common line which can be read and heard all over the world. There has been a lot of initiatives to protect the planet Earth from unbridled human developments. Although some people argue these developments are making our life comfortable, but concerns to save Earth are vital due to various reasons.Firstly, rapid development of infrastructure is eating most of the forest throughout world. The so-called Concrete jungles have evolved endangering forests and wild life. As we all know life saving oxygen is produced by trees after converting harmful carbon dioxide gas. Moreover, wild life is very essential to maintain ecological balance on planet Earth.Secondly, large emissions of carbon monoxide gas from refrigerants like air conditioners have depleted ozone layer. Importance of ozone layer is evident by the fact as it protects us from harmful ultra violet rays. To add to it, excess emission of carbon dioxide gas mainly by vehicles around the world has increased the average temperature at north pole which in turn has increased water level due to gradual melting of glaciers.Lastly, either industrial waste or domestic waste produced everyday is badly polluting the planet Earth. For instance a large amount of unnoticed industrial waste released in oceans effects aquatic life to a large extent. Harmful chemicals present in industrial waste kills lot of sea creatures in oceans or rivers.To conclude, Earth is our home and it should be protected. Any human activity causing harm to Earth should be controlled and alternate ways should be devised to control damage. Creative ideas should be encouraged to leave minimum environmental footprints without compromising quality of life.
llm: The debate about the impact of human activities on the Earth has sparked intense discussion in recent years. While some argue that our actions are enhancing the quality of life on the planet, I firmly believe that humans are harming the Earth through our activities.The evidence of environmental degradation is overwhelming. Deforestation, pollution, climate change, and species extinction are just a few examples of the devastating consequences of human actions. The excessive use of fossil fuels, for instance, has led to a significant increase in greenhouse gas emissions, resulting in rising temperatures and more frequent natural disasters. Moreover, the rampant pollution of our oceans and waterways has not only harmed marine life but also contaminated the food chain, posing a significant threat to human health.On the other hand, some may argue that human activities have improved the quality of life on Earth by providing better infrastructure, technology, and healthcare. However, these advancements come at a steep environmental cost. The production and disposal of technology, for example, contribute to electronic waste and pollution, while the expansion of infrastructure often leads to habitat destruction and loss of biodiversity.In conclusion, the harm caused by human activities to the Earth far outweighs any perceived benefits. It is imperative that we take immediate action to mitigate the damage and adopt sustainable practices to preserve the planet for future generations. This can be achieved through a collective effort to reduce our carbon footprint, conserve natural resources, and protect endangered species. Ultimately, it is our responsibility to ensure that our actions do not irreparably harm the planet, but rather contribute to its preservation and prosperity.

question: Some people believe that in order to give opportunities to new generations, companies should encourage high level employees who are older than 55 to retire. Do you agree or disagree?
human: Nowadays the discussion about whether the businesses are supposed to prescribe the retirement age at fifty-five to offer more job vacancies for younger generation has become a controversy. Some believe that is a perfect attempt to support the young, others claim that this is not the case.Admittedly, encouraging the workers to retire at age of fifty-five to release the positions for younger job seekers has some merits. Firstly, fresh graduates are likely to bring a number of practical and applicable ideas to meet the current needs of the organisation. This is because they have been instilled and imparted the most updated knowledge and skills at universities. Secondly, having a larger proportion of young adults could enhance the working effectiveness and efficiency. Compared with aged staffs, younger employees are often physically stronger and energetic which enables them to carry out heavy workload to meet the deadline.However, sacrificing the senior members to save the young workers poses several negative influences. From personal level, it fosters a sense of unfairness between the older and younger generations. It is undeniable that every person within the business enterprise has the rights to proceed their work as long as they are capable of doing it, disregard the age and physical capacity. From social perspective, massively forcing the early retirement would be one of financial burden to the local government. For example, sufficient pension payments and regular medical care should be given and arranged for the senior citizens after they have been imposed to terminate their employment permanently.In conclusion, even though the introduction of the early retirement has some benefits, it is convincing that it would generate a sense of discrimination among different age groups and increase the government financial pressure accordingly.
llm: The idea that companies should encourage high-level employees over 55 to retire to give opportunities to new generations is a contentious issue. While some argue that this approach can inject fresh perspectives and ideas into a company, I disagree with this stance.On one hand, it is true that retiring older employees can create vacancies, allowing younger talent to step up and take on new challenges. This can lead to innovation and diversity in the workplace, as new generations bring unique experiences and skills to the table. However, this approach overlooks the value and contributions that experienced employees can continue to make.On the other hand, older employees often possess valuable knowledge, expertise, and leadership skills, honed over years of service. Forcing them into retirement can result in a significant loss of institutional memory and mentorship opportunities. Many older employees are still highly productive and motivated, and their experience can be instrumental in guiding and training younger colleagues. Moreover, with the increasing lifespan and health of the population, many people over 55 are still capable of making significant contributions to their organizations.Rather than encouraging retirement, companies should focus on creating a work environment that values and utilizes the skills of all employees, regardless of age. This can involve providing opportunities for knowledge transfer, mentoring, and flexible work arrangements that cater to different stages of life. By embracing age diversity and promoting intergenerational collaboration, companies can leverage the strengths of both older and younger employees, and create a more dynamic and successful organization. In conclusion, while the intention behind encouraging older employees to retire may be to give opportunities to new generations, it is not a strategy that I agree with.

question: Some people believe that the media, such as the press, TV and internet should be more strictly controlled. Others feel that controls should be loosened to give people freer access to information. Which opinion do you agree with?
human: Nowadays, one of the most controversial issues related to mass media is the correct amount of control posed on newspapers, televisions and websites. It is argued that the government should exercise less restriction on sharing of media information to public. However, I strongly believe that it should increase the level of control to protect the public against inappropriate contents and unsuitable foreign cultures.One of the strong arguments in favour of tighter media control is to limit the violent and sexual content. They have a serious impact on people in their puberty. For example, an internet cartoon comedy called happy tree is extremely brutal, where the characters usually have their heads or limbs tear off. Another supporting reason is that television companies import foreign programmes from time to time and audiences might accept their ideas which maybe otherwise not welcomed to local culture. A few years ago there was a Japanese game show which involved throwing cream cakes to the loser. This is actually very environmentally unfriendly.The major opposing argument is to protect the safety of citizens. In other words, the government should disclose the information to the media in a timely manner, especially for disasters and outbreak of new diseases. Taking the SARS in 2003 as an example, the Chinese government limited the amount of information for public access which therefore causes numerous deaths. Even so, another perspective on this is to prevent the citizen from unnecessary fear and unrest.Both sides of the arguments have its merits. My personal view is that despite the emphasis of citizen safety, the government should regulate the correct amount of violent and sexual content and censor the culturally unsuitable information. Setting up a council to monitor the media information to the public could be a practical idea.
llm: The debate surrounding media control has been a longstanding one, with some advocating for stricter regulations and others pushing for greater freedom of access to information. After careful consideration, I firmly believe that controls on the media should be loosened to provide people with freer access to information.On one hand, a completely unregulated media landscape can lead to the dissemination of false or misleading information, as well as the exploitation of sensitive or explicit content. However, I believe that the benefits of a more open media system far outweigh the potential drawbacks. By loosening controls, people are granted unhindered access to a wide range of information, allowing them to make informed decisions and engage in thoughtful discussions.Moreover, strict media controls can often be used as a tool for censorship, stifling dissenting voices and limiting the exchange of ideas. In a democratic society, the free flow of information is essential for holding those in power accountable and promoting transparency. By giving people greater access to information, we empower them to participate in the democratic process and contribute to the development of a more informed and engaged citizenry.Ultimately, while some regulation may be necessary to prevent the spread of harmful or explicit content, I believe that the media should be subject to minimal control. By trusting people to discern and critically evaluate the information presented to them, we can foster a more open, informed, and democratic society. Loosening controls on the media is essential for promoting freedom of expression, access to information, and the exchange of ideas, all of which are fundamental to a healthy and functioning democracy.

question: Some people think that paying taxes is enough to contribute to the society. Others argue that being a citizen involves more responsibilities. Discuss, what is your opinion?
human: There is a controversial debate around the world about the duties of citizen. Some people believe that paying tax is the only responsibility of citizens, while others disagree and think that being a person in society involves more responsibilities.Taxes are the income for every country in the world and they are extremely important for developing countries. If people are paying taxes, that means they are taking part in the development of their country as well as the country's economy. Therefore, they have fulfilled their duty as a citizen.Some people argue that individuals of a country are responsible for many other things apart from paying tax. In fact, in order to develop a country, citizens must obey laws, which were imposed by the government. In this way, the crime rate is reduced and society becomes a peaceful place, so the country will develop at a rapid pace. Furthermore, being a citizen in society should protect the country's culture and history. For instance, people should have knowledge about their own culture and history by studying at school with full concentration or reading them from books. On the other hand, a person has to unite with other people in the community so as to develop their nation. Indeed, if people in society have a strong bond with each other, society will become a peaceful place, where people are helping and sharing to each other.Taking everything into account, I strongly believe that being a citizen involves in a number of duties, other than paying taxes. People in society must do more than paying taxes to contribute to their society.
llm: The notion that paying taxes is sufficient to contribute to society has sparked a debate among individuals. While some people believe that fulfilling tax obligations is enough, others argue that being a citizen entails more responsibilities. In my opinion, I agree with the latter viewpoint.Paying taxes is undoubtedly a crucial aspect of being a citizen, as it helps fund public services and infrastructure. However, it is merely one facet of the broader spectrum of civic responsibilities. Citizens have a moral obligation to engage with their community, participate in the democratic process, and contribute to the well-being of society. This can be achieved through volunteering, community service, and active participation in local governance.Moreover, being an informed and responsible citizen involves staying updated on current events, critically evaluating information, and making informed decisions. It also entails respecting the rights and dignity of fellow citizens, promoting social cohesion, and advocating for the common good. By adopting these values, citizens can create a more harmonious and equitable society.In conclusion, while paying taxes is an essential duty of citizenship, it is by no means the only responsibility. Being a citizen involves a multifaceted commitment to the community, the environment, and the democratic process. As responsible citizens, we must strive to go beyond merely fulfilling our tax obligations and actively engage with our community to create a better world for future generations. By doing so, we can foster a sense of shared ownership and collective responsibility, ultimately leading to a more prosperous and harmonious society. Ultimately, being a citizen is not just about paying taxes, but about embracing a broader range of responsibilities that contribute to the greater good.

question: Testing on animals should be made illegal. Agree or disagree?
human: Perhaps the most serious problem facing the animals' rights today is animal experimentation. Many medical treatments have been discovered by animal testing, including cancer and HIV drugs While most scientists claim that this is vital for improving human health, I believe that primates should have the same rights as human beings.There are several reasons why animal testing should be banned. Firstly, the costs outweigh the benefits. Every year, cosmetic companies, farms or medical schools kill millions of animals to test their products, without any beneficial result. Animal testing costs an enormous amount of money, since they must be fed, cared for and treated with drugs or experimental substances.Secondly, animals are kept in unnatural conditions. Recent studies point out that animals are neglected and treated poorly, which influences their reactions to drugs. In March 2003, a lab technician shot a video inside a lab, which revealed primates in cages without pain medication, for instance one baboon with a metal cylinder screwed into its head. Consequently, I think that sacrificing animals is an expensive and painful activity.There is also the argument that many ethical and genetic principles are broken when testing on animals. Many people agree that it is not only inhumane and cruel to cause pain to animals, but also misleading, since animals and people's response to a drug can be different. I personally believe that human beings have no moral right to use animals in ways that do not benefit the individual.For the reasons mentioned above, it seems to me that testing on animals has no clear result and consequently, it should be made illegal.
llm: The debate on whether testing on animals should be made illegal has been a contentious issue for many years. In my opinion, I strongly agree that testing on animals should be made illegal. The use of animals in scientific research and product testing is a cruel and inhumane practice that raises serious ethical concerns.Firstly, animal testing is often unnecessary and unreliable. Many alternative methods, such as computer simulations and human clinical trials, can provide more accurate and relevant results. Furthermore, the use of animals in testing can lead to false or misleading results, as animals may react differently to substances than humans do. This can result in the development of ineffective or even harmful treatments.Moreover, animal testing is a barbaric practice that causes immense suffering and harm to innocent animals. Every year, millions of animals are subjected to painful and distressing procedures, including toxicity testing, skin and eye irritation tests, and lethal dose tests. These animals are often kept in inhumane conditions, without adequate food, water, or shelter, and are eventually killed at the end of the testing process.In addition, there are many examples of successful alternatives to animal testing that have already been developed. For instance, many cosmetics companies have switched to using in vitro testing methods, which use human skin cells in a laboratory to test the safety and efficacy of their products. Similarly, many pharmaceutical companies are now using computer simulations and human clinical trials to test new drugs, rather than relying on animal models.In conclusion, testing on animals is an outdated, cruel, and unnecessary practice that should be made illegal. With the development of alternative methods, there is no longer a need to subject animals to painful and distressing procedures. It is our moral obligation to treat animals with respect and kindness, and to protect them from harm and exploitation.

question: Many people believe that formal "pen and paper" examinations are not the best method of assessing educational achievement. What is your view of examinations?Ê
human: Examinations are one of the most common methods of measuring learning in education systems throughout the world. At virtually every stage of the learning process, exams are used to verify that the learner is ready to move on to the next stage. However, many believe that the role of examinations should be reconsidered.There are clearly advantages to exams. They help to ensure fairness by imposing the same conditions on all exam candidates. They are also relatively versatile; different types of exam questions, for example, multiple-choice questions and essay tasks, can test different sorts of reasoning ability. However, exams also have some drawbacks. Test-wise candidates can often perform well on exams without having good underlying knowledge or skills. In contrast, some test-takers perform cannot achieve a satisfying result because of anxiety. In this case, teachers and learners focus only on theses aspects of the curriculum that are likely to be tested, thus narrowing the educational experience for all.A number of measures should be taken to address these concerns. Wherever possible, exams should match the content and activities of the learning environment. Exam task should be varied to give fair opportunities to candidates with different types of skills. Other types of assessment should also be considered, assignment writing, for example, to assess independent learning and research skills, or group projects, to measure teamwork ability.In conclusion, it is convincing that exams have a role to play in ensuring proper and objective assessment of achievement. However, exams need to be carefully designed and supplemented with other forms of evaluation if they are to be a truly useful component of the education system.
llm: The effectiveness of formal "pen and paper" examinations as a means of assessing educational achievement has been a topic of debate for a long time. While some people believe that examinations are a necessary evil, others argue that they are not the best method of evaluation. In my view, the traditional examination system has several drawbacks that make it an outdated and inefficient way of assessing students' knowledge and skills.One of the main criticisms of examinations is that they only test a student's ability to memorize and recall information, rather than their understanding and application of it. This can lead to a narrow focus on rote learning, rather than encouraging critical thinking and problem-solving skills. Furthermore, examinations can be a source of significant stress and anxiety for students, which can negatively impact their performance and overall well-being.Another limitation of examinations is that they do not account for individual differences in learning styles and abilities. Some students may excel in a traditional exam setting, while others may struggle, despite having a deep understanding of the subject matter. Additionally, examinations often prioritize theoretical knowledge over practical skills, which can make it difficult for students to apply what they have learned in real-world situations.In conclusion, while examinations have been a staple of the educational system for centuries, they are not the best method of assessing educational achievement. They prioritize memorization over understanding, create unnecessary stress, and fail to account for individual differences in learning styles. Alternative assessment methods, such as project-based evaluations and competency-based progression, should be explored to provide a more comprehensive and effective way of evaluating student learning. By moving away from traditional examinations, we can create a more inclusive and supportive learning environment that allows students to reach their full potential.

question: Improvements in health, education and trade are essential for the development of poorer nations. However, the governments of richer nations should take more responsibility for helping the poorer nations in such areas.
human: Improvements in health, education and trade are essential for the development of poorer nations. Poorer nations need help from richer nations in these areas to develop their countries.Firstly, in the area of health, poorer nations normally have less quantity of doctors and nurses compared to richer nations. High population in poorer countries due to lack of family planning caused the proportion of doctors unbalance to the quantity of resident. On top of that, poorer nations are lack of hospitals to fulfill the demand of the patients. To solve these issues, richer nations can contribute by delegating doctors and nurses to these power nations as well as donate money to build hospitals.Secondly, in the area of education, it is generally agreed that poorer countries often lack of teachers in schools as well as lecturers in higher education institutions. Besides that, education for these countries normally is not free so only certain group of students can afford it. In order to solve the education manpower problem, richer countries can allocate experienced educators to train more teachers and lecturers in poorer countries. Meanwhile, for the issue of education fee, richer countries should offer scholarships and loan to the qualified students.Lastly, in the area of trade, no one can deny that poorer countries are lagging behind richer countries due to shortage of money. Trading are less active in poorer countries may also be caused by incomplete transportation infrastructure. For example, residents in rural areas still depend on their own farm for food production. As a token of goodwill, richer nations can provide financial service to poorer countries to encourage trading. The former can also give consultation on setting up a complete and efficient transportation infrastructure to support trading.In conclusion, richer nations should take more responsibility for helping the poorer nations in all health, education and trade. Improvements in these areas will create a better life for residents in poorer nations which they can use to grow their homeland.
llm: The development of poorer nations is a pressing concern that requires a multifaceted approach. Improvements in health, education, and trade are indeed essential for the growth and prosperity of these nations. However, it is crucial that the governments of richer nations take a more active role in supporting their less fortunate counterparts in these areas.Health and education are the foundation upon which a nation's development is built. In poorer nations, these sectors are often underfunded and understaffed, leading to a lack of access to basic healthcare and quality education. The governments of richer nations can make a significant impact by providing financial assistance, donating medical supplies and equipment, and sending medical professionals and educators to share their expertise. This not only improves the health and education outcomes in poorer nations but also helps to build a skilled and productive workforce.Trade is another critical area where richer nations can offer support. By reducing trade barriers and providing preferential market access, richer nations can help poorer nations to increase their exports and stimulate economic growth. Additionally, richer nations can share their knowledge and technology to help poorer nations develop their infrastructure and industries. This can include investing in transportation systems, communication networks, and energy production, which are essential for economic development.In conclusion, the development of poorer nations requires a collaborative effort from the international community. The governments of richer nations have a moral obligation to assist their less fortunate counterparts in improving health,,assistanteducation, and trade. By providing financial and technical assistance, richer nations can help poorer nations to break the cycle of poverty and achieve sustainable development. It is essential that richer nations take a more proactive approach to supporting poorer nations, not only as a moral imperative but also as a sound investment in global stability and prosperity. By working together, we can create a more equitable and prosperous world for all nations.

question: As computers are being used more and more in education, there will be soon no role for teachers in the classroom. Agree or disagree.
human: In recent years it has become more common for teachers to use technological tools in the learning process. However, I do not agree that this explosion in technology will 'innovate' the education system, by replacing teachers with computers.There are several reasons why teachers will never be replaced by computers. Firstly, computers need to be operated by people. No one can argue that technological tools are must-haves for the classroom of today. For example, lessons are more attractive and easier to understand when they are put on a Power Point presentation and then presented with a LCD Projector. However, scientists prove that every classroom needs trained staff to use these interactive and innovative ways of teaching. I agree that nowadays the learning process benefits greatly from computers, but they are just tools for teachers and they cannot work properly without human's touch.Secondly, children need human interactions. No matter how advanced technology will be, it is clear that a computer will never be able to communicate with its pupils. As a recent interview with Josh Trumm – the founder of the 'Teachers Global Group'- reveals, human interactions will never be imitated by computers: 'This verbal and non-verbal communication between teachers and children is the first step towards a proper education. Without someone who can explain and understand their problems, pupils cannot actually learn'. I am inclined to agree with this scientific view, because only a teacher can feel and connect with pupils, be a friend and a model.In conclusion, there can be no school without a teacher. I think that computers will continue to be used by teachers in the learning process, but they will never take their place. Teachers are not just teachers, they are also friends and conseilieurs.
llm: The increasing use of computers in education has sparked a debate about the future role of teachers in the classroom. While some argue that computers will eventually replace teachers, I strongly disagree. Computers are excellent tools for supplementing learning, but they lack the human touch and interpersonal skills that teachers bring to the classroom.Computers can provide students with access to a vast amount of information and educational resources, but they cannot replace the guidance, support, and feedback that teachers offer. Teachers play a crucial role in helping students understand complex concepts, answering questions, and providing individualized attention. They also help students develop important life skills such as communication, teamwork, and problem-solving, which are essential for success in the real world.Furthermore, teaching is not just about imparting knowledge, but also about inspiring, motivating, and mentoring students. Teachers have the ability to create a supportive and inclusive learning environment, which is essential for students' emotional and social development. Computers, on the other hand, are limited in their ability to provide emotional support and empathy, which are essential for students' well-being and academic success.In conclusion, while computers will continue to play an increasingly important role in education, they will not replace teachers in the classroom. Teachers bring a unique set of skills, experience, and human qualities that are essential for providing high-quality education. Rather than replacing teachers, computers will augment their role, allowing them to focus on what they do best: providing individualized support, guidance, and inspiration to students. Ultimately, the effective use of computers in education will enhance the teaching process, but it will not make teachers redundant.

question: Food can be produced cheaper if we use improved fertilisers and better machinery. However some of methods may be dangerous for human health, and have negative effects for local communities. What is your opinion?
human: In recent years, the discussion about the agriculture development has become a controversy. While some appear to believe that advanced plant foods incorporate with newly developed devices significantly reduce the cost of producing farm products, others argue that this collaboration exerts a series of negative effects to people's health condition and the society.Admittedly, applying the advanced fertilizers in combine with the automatic reaping resources increase farmers' economic profit. This is because artificial fertilizers catalyze the capacity of each inch of farmland in order to churn out the crops, and automatic machinery enhances the work efficiency of the harvest. Consequently, the production and labour cost of each kilogram of the agriculture products dramatically decreased.However, high-tech fertilizers pose a potential threat to individuals' health well-being. Unlike the organic plant foods, industrialized fertilizers are made of unusual chemicals, which are not only varying the gene of crops into those unknown substances but also remaining inside of plants permanently. In this case, consumers who intake those fertilized products on a regular base tend to suffer a series of disease in the future.Moreover, excessively relying on the electronic equipment for harvest causes several impacts to the society. One is that it worsens the air pollution by releasing the excessive exhaust emission. In contrast, manual harvest prevents severe environmental damages. For another, mechanical reaper causes the rise of the unemployment rate in the farming industry, possibly because high-end reaping plants replace a large number of workers in the fields.In conclusion, even though newly developed plant foods and machinery make significant financial success for the farmers, it is convincing that the demerits of applying these new developments in the agriculture industry cannot be overlooked.
llm: The use of improved fertilisers and better machinery in food production has sparked a debate about the trade-offs between cost efficiency and potential risks to human health and local communities. On one hand, the implementation of modern agricultural techniques can significantly reduce production costs, making food more affordable and accessible to a wider population. This is particularly beneficial for low-income households and individuals who struggle to make ends meet.On the other hand, the use of certain fertilisers and machinery can have detrimental effects on human health and the environment. For instance, some fertilisers contain chemicals that can contaminate soil, water, and air, leading to respiratory problems and other health issues. Moreover, the intensive farming practices that rely on heavy machinery can lead to soil erosion, water pollution, and loss of biodiversity. Local communities may also be negatively impacted, as the increased use of machinery can lead to job losses and the displacement of small-scale farmers.In my opinion, while the use of improved fertilisers and better machinery can make food production cheaper, it is not worth the potential risks to human health and the environment. Instead, I believe that sustainable and organic farming practices should be prioritized, even if they are more expensive. These methods may require more labor and resources, but they ensure that food is produced in a way that is safe for consumption and respectful of the environment. Furthermore, supporting local and small-scale farmers can help maintain the social and economic fabric of rural communities. Ultimately, the true cost of food production should take into account not only the monetary cost but also the environmental and social costs.

question: Some people think that government should spend money on other important subjects rather helping artists. Do you agree or disagree?
human: Nowadays, in order to save as much budget as possible and improve the economy of the country, every government around the world is seeking for some ways to spend wisely. Therefore, there is a suggestion that governments should not continue to fund the artists, but they ought to spend money on other necessary subjects such as medical research and space. In my view, I firmly disagree with this recommendation due to several reasons.The main reason why I believe artists should be funded is because art helps to improve the quality of our lives as well as attracting tourists. For example, monuments that represent each city do not only illustrate the city's history and culture, but also make the city more beautiful and an attractive place for tourists. In fact, some countries depend on tourism as their main source of revenue, thus, the governments should help arts because their work crafts are very necessary to boost the tourist industry.In addition, sculptures and paintings in the museums and art galleries generally reflect the culture and civilization of every generation. Therefore, culture and history of a country can be reserved and assured by art. Young people are also able to get more knowledge about their country's history and culture by observing various work crafts.Another reason why artists should be helped is because talent in art is extremely precious and should not be wasted. Indeed, not many people are blessed in the talent of paintings and work crafts. Hence, this type of talent has to be valued as other types of talents such as talent in science or literature.To sum up, art is a very valuable object for every country and the talent in this area cannot be discovered everywhere, so I think governments should help and encourage artists to continue their work.
llm: The notion that government should allocate its funds to more pressing areas rather than supporting artists has sparked a contentious debate. While some argue that the financial resources of a nation should be directed towards essential public services and infrastructure, I firmly disagree with this perspective.First and foremost, art plays a pivotal role in the cultural and historical identity of a nation. Artists, through their work, contribute to the preservation and promotion of a country's heritage, thereby enriching its societal fabric. By supporting artists, the government essentially invests in the nation's cultural capital, which has long-term benefits that transcend monetary value. It fosters a sense of community and national pride, elements that are crucial for the well-being and unity of a society.Moreover, the arts sector is a significant contributor to the economy. It generates employment opportunities not just for artists but also for a myriad of professionals involved in the production, exhibition, and sale of art. Additionally, a thriving arts scene can boost tourism, attracting visitors who are interested in experiencing the unique cultural offerings of a country. This, in turn, can lead to substantial revenue for local businesses and the government through tourism-related activities.It is also worth considering that the amount of money spent on supporting artists is typically a fraction of the government's overall budget. When compared to the allocations for defense, healthcare, and education, the arts usually receive a minimal portion. Therefore, the argument that funding the arts diverts money away from more critical areas does not hold substantial ground, as the impact of arts funding on the overall budget is relatively minor.In conclusion, while it is understandable that people might prioritize other public expenditures over arts funding, I believe that supporting artists is a vital investment in a nation's cultural, economic, and social development. It is not a question of either/or, but rather about achieving a balanced allocation of resources that recognizes the value of art in enriching and defining a society.

question: Development in technology causes environmental problems. Some people believe the solution in these problems is everyone accepts a simpler way of life, while others say that technology can solve these problems. Discuss both view and give your own opinion.Ê
human: It is irrefutable that progress in technology leads to environmental problems. Some individuals are of the opinion that if people live a simple life and do not use the things that technology has brought us then these problems can be solved whereas others opine that only technology can solve these problems. In the following paragraphs, I intend to discuss both viewpoints.Some people say that if humans stop using technology and lead a simple way of life then only we can save the environment. They argue that it is the luxuries people use which damages the environment. If people don't use air conditioners, automobiles and other such things that technology has brought us, then naturally there would be less pollution and natural resources like fossil fuels would be saved and all this would save the environment.On the other hand there are people who say that technology alone could save the environment. They opine that now we have come so far ahead in technology that there is no going back. We cannot ask the people of the jet age to go back to the age of the bullock cart.There are a lot of advances going on technology which are helping the environment a lot. One prime example is finding solutions to water problems in developing countries such as Africa. By pressurising sea water to produce vapour jets and filtering them through carbon nano tubes, we can get clean drinking water from sea water - an almost inexhaustible resource. Furthermore, Japan is working to build a working space solar power system by 2030. By drawing on the colossal energy of the sun, it could meet the entire world's electricity requirements indefinitely without nuclear or GHG emissions. If successful, the impact on the world would be monumental. It would mean energy for schools, hospitals, and homes. It would mean another industrial revolution.To put it in a nutshell, I pen down saying that, technology alone can solve the world's environmental problems. We are finally entering an era where engineering and technology are making the world a better place. It would be highly unpractical to ask people to adopt a simpler way of life.
llm: The development of technology has undoubtedly led to numerous environmental problems, including pollution, climate change, and depletion of natural resources. In response to these issues, two distinct perspectives have emerged. On one hand, some people argue that embracing a simpler way of life is the key to mitigating these environmental problems. They suggest that by adopting more modest lifestyles, reducing consumption, and relying less on technology, we can significantly decrease our ecological footprint. This approach emphasizes the need for individuals to make conscious choices about their daily habits and behaviors, such as using public transport, recycling, and conserving energy.On the other hand, others believe that technology itself holds the solution to the environmental problems it has created. Proponents of this view argue that advancements in technology can provide innovative and efficient solutions to environmental challenges. For instance, renewable energy sources, green technologies, and sustainable manufacturing processes can all contribute to reducing the harmful impacts of human activity on the environment. Moreover, technology can facilitate more accurate monitoring and management of environmental resources, enabling more effective conservation and preservation efforts.In my opinion, while a simpler way of life can certainly contribute to reducing environmental problems, the potential of technology to solve these issues should not be underestimated. Technology has the capacity to drive significant positive change, and its continued development can lead to more sustainable and environmentally-friendly practices. However, it is crucial that technological advancements are pursued with environmental considerations in mind, ensuring that solutions are developed with sustainability as a core objective. Ultimately, a balanced approach that combines the benefits of technology with mindful, environmentally-conscious lifestyle choices is likely to be the most effective strategy for addressing the environmental problems caused by technological development.

question: Professional athletes (such as football stars) and entertainers (such as singers and actors) are paid too much money for the work they do. Use specific details and examples to support your answer.
human: Some people believe that professional athletes and entertainers are paid reasonable salaries, which can be up to millions of dollars each year. However, that is not equal to their actual contributions to the society. I believe that their salary at a lower level would be more appropriate compared with other peoples in scientific or social, economic fields.First of all, some people claim that athletes and singers deserve their current salary because they have an exceptional ability that other people do not own. For example, hardly anyone could play basketball as skillfully as Michael Jordan - a legendary former American player who won several times in the NBA championship. They also point out that these people have to undergo painstaking and industrious training, let alone participate in a great number of contests to be recognized and prove themselves. In addition, although there are many singers and athletes, few of whom could rise to fame and victory ultimately. Overcoming all these obstacles, they should be paid a great deal of money for their extraordinary efforts. However, their talents should not be overrated. Other people say that singers and athletes, in fact, contribute insignificantly to the development of the society. It is assumed the amazing performances they give to the audiences are only valuable in aesthetic and entertaining terms. While scientists invent machines serving daily lives, doctors take care of patients and cure their diseases and policemen help to ensure the safety and stability of the nation, singers and athletes do not play a helpful part in improving the material life. They commit themselves to promoting relaxation and enjoyment for the audience. Indeed, their contribution is less important than those from doctors or scientists, albeit necessary. Hence, their privilege of salary seems groundless, while the main work forces receive modest salaries which only enable them to afford bare necessities.From all analysis suggested above, professional athletes and singers are overpaid in terms of their contributions. I think that there should be a modification in the salary of professional singers and athletes to balance with those of people in other fields, namely science and society, who are the driving forces for the prosperity of the nation.
llm: The debate about whether professional athletes and entertainers are overpaid has been a longstanding one. In my opinion, professional athletes and entertainers are indeed paid too much money for the work they do. The salaries of top football stars, such as Cristiano Ronaldo and Lionel Messi, are staggering, with some earning over $100 million per year. Similarly, the paychecks of A-list actors and singers, such as Dwayne Johnson and Taylor Swift, can reach up to $50 million per movie or album.One argument against these high salaries is that they are disproportionate to the value they bring to society. While entertainers and athletes do bring joy and entertainment to millions of people, their work is not as essential as that of doctors, teachers, or social workers, who are often underpaid and overworked. For example, the average salary of a teacher in the United States is around $60,000 per year, a fraction of what many athletes and entertainers earn in a single performance or game.Furthermore, the high salaries of professional athletes and entertainers can have negative consequences, such as inflating the cost of living and perpetuating income inequality. The money that goes into the pockets of these celebrities could be better spent on more pressing social issues, such as education, healthcare, and poverty alleviation. Additionally, the emphasis on material wealth and fame can create unrealistic expectations and promote a culture of excess and narcissism.In conclusion, while professional athletes and entertainers do bring value to society, their salaries are excessive and disproportionate to the value they bring. It is time for us to reevaluate our priorities and consider a more equitable distribution of wealth, one that rewards and values the contributions of all individuals, regardless of their profession.

question: Some people think that computers and the Internet are more important for a child's education than going to school. But others believe that schools and teachers are essential for children to learn effectively. Discuss both views and give your own opinion.
human: With the number of technological advances growing apace, it is generally believed that Internet and computers will supplant the traditional role of teachers in a not too distant future. This idea may point out to two main directions, both of which present different arguments.Central to the supporting arguments of this issue is the idea that the global online network is the inexhaustible source of information, which definitely exceeds the fund of knowledge that any veteran teacher can accumulate. Internet and computer also offer a more comprehensive access to knowledge, ranging from visual to aural stimuli, which make learning an ever enjoyable experience, especially for children.On the other hand, critics of this idea maintain that although the educational benefits that the Internet may yield are undeniable, there still remain certain shortcomings. Much information as the Internet may provide, most of the sources are unjustified by experts. As a result, information from those sources is subject to question. Admittedly, the computer can show whether an answer to a particular question is right or wrong but it cannot give as an in-depth explanation as a human teacher can. Through face-to-face communication, teachers can also pinpoint the weaknesses of each student and therefore, adjusting and tailoring his or her teaching methodology to meet the levels or the demands of those students. This is where the computer proves to be incompetent.In short, although both sides have their equally valid arguments, I am inclined to think that although Internet can be a useful tool for education, at no time will the unique role of human teachers be replaced.
llm: The debate surrounding the importance of computers and the Internet versus traditional schooling in a child's education has sparked intense discussion. On one hand, some individuals argue that computers and the Internet have become indispensable tools for a child's education, as they provide unparalleled access to a vast array of information and educational resources. With the Internet, a child can learn at their own pace, access educational materials from around the world, and engage in interactive learning experiences that can be more effective than traditional teaching methods.On the other hand, there are those who firmly believe that schools and teachers are essential for children to learn effectively. They argue that schools provide a structured learning environment, social interaction, and the guidance of experienced teachers, which are crucial for a child's cognitive, intellectual, and emotional development. Teachers can tailor their teaching methods to meet the individual needs of each student, offer immediate feedback, and help children develop important life skills such as communication, teamwork, and problem-solving.In my opinion, the ideal approach to a child's education is a balance between the use of computers and the Internet, and the traditional school setting. While technology can provide access to a wealth of information and innovative learning tools, the role of teachers and the social aspect of schooling are irreplaceable. Schools offer children the opportunity to interact with peers, develop social skills, and receive the support and guidance necessary for their overall development.
